image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Representative from Massachusetts; born in Boston, Mass., December 21, 1829; moved with his parents to Hopkinton in 1830 and to Worcester, Mass., in 1843; attended the public schools; engaged in the manufacture of boots and shoes; established the business of manufacturing leather in Chicago, Ill., in 1868; member of the common council of Worcester 1852-1854; served in the State house of representatives in 1879, 1880, and 1887; elected as a Republican to the Fifty-first and to the four succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1889-March 3, 1899); chairman, Committee on Banking and Currency (Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Congresses); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1898 to the Fifty-sixth Congress; resumed his former business pursuits; died in Worcester, Mass., April 3, 1907; interment in the Rural Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Walker, Joseph Henry. Banking: An address delivered (by invitation) before the Boston Association of Bank Presidents at the Parker House, Boston, November 14, 1892, with an appendix containing a draft of the proposed banking bill now being considered by the House Committee on Banking and Currency. Worcester, Mass.: N.p., 1893.
------. Bankruptcy. Protection to the debtor as well as the creditor. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1898.
------. A few facts and suggestions on money, trade, and banking. Boston and New York: Houghton, Mifflin and Company 1882.
------. Hawaii. Annexation justified in the interests of peace and an honourable [sic] discharge of duty. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1898.
------. Let us pay our debts. Reimbursing educational institutions for losses after the war closed. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1898.
------. Not free coinage of silver, but a change of the measure of value. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1892.
------. Parsimony in public expenditure; remarks in the House of Representatives, March 9 and 10, 1894. Washington: N.p., 1894.

------. Remarks of Hon. J. H. Walker, of Massachusetts, of the House of Representatives before the Committee on Banking and Currency, Dec. 19, 1893, explaining and commending Banking bill H. R. 171. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1893.
------. Silver and gold. Tax on options and futures. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1894.

------. [Speeches and addresses of] Hon. J. H. Walker, of Massachusetts, ten years member of, eight years first Republican named on, and four years chairman of Committee on Banking and Currency, national House of Representatives, 1889-99. [Worcester, Mass.: N.p., 1900].
------. The tariff. Wages. Manufacturers' profits. Canadian tariff. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1890.
------. The true history of the legislation in the act of July 14, 1890. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1898.

------. Uniform hours of labor: Legislation asked from a humanitarian standpoint; remarks before the Committee on the Judiciary, House of Representatives, Friday, February 18, 1898. [Washington?: N.p., 1898].
------. Why the purchase clause of the act of July 14, 1890 (called Sherman law) should be repealed, and why free coinage of silver would be unjust. [Washington: Government Printing Office], 1893.
